channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: JWST spots what could be a quasar from the early Universe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02429-4

The object’s deep red colour suggests it existed when the Universe was less than 700 million years old.
item.dc:title: JWST spots what could be a quasar from the early Universe

item.title: Cutting ships’ pollution has climate downside
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02430-x

Rules on the fuel burned by ships at sea implemented in 2020 lead to local changes in cloud chemistry.
item.dc:title: Cutting ships’ pollution has climate downside

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals the living descendants of enslaved people through 23andMe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02478-9

A landmark genomic study raises the possibility that many more people could find links to distant ancestors through genetic analysis.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals the living descendants of enslaved people through 23andMe
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Dr Semmelweis review: Mark Rylance play shows how hand washing saved hundreds of lives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02493-w

Professional pride and personal tragedy stymied ideas about how infections spread in the nineteenth century, suggests a show about maverick Hungarian doctor Ignaz Semmelweis.
item.dc:title: Dr Semmelweis review: Mark Rylance play shows how hand washing saved hundreds of lives
item.dc:creator: Georgina Ferry

item.title: How the ‘groundbreaking’ Henrietta Lacks settlement could change research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02479-8

Thermo Fisher Scientific and Lacks’s family reach a deal over the unethical use of her cells.
item.dc:title: How the ‘groundbreaking’ Henrietta Lacks settlement could change research
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza
Mariana Lenharo

item.title: ‘It’s a dream’: JWST spies more black holes than astronomers predicted
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02460-5

The James Webb Space Telescope’s observations could help to answer questions about how the celestial objects formed early in the Universe.
item.dc:title: ‘It’s a dream’: JWST spies more black holes than astronomers predicted
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: How Beijing's deadly floods could be avoided
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01258-9

The floods that have swept China in the past week were exacerbated by poor planning for drainage.
item.dc:title: How Beijing's deadly floods could be avoided
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Reply to: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06293-0

Reply to: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:title: Reply to: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Fangxi Xu
Deepak Saxena
Smruti Pushalkar
George Miller

item.title: How to get more women in science, with Athene Donald
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02467-y

The experimental physicist joins us to talk about her book Not just for the boys, why we need more women in science.
item.dc:title: How to get more women in science, with Athene Donald
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Synthesis and properties of cyclic sandwich compounds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06192-4

The design, synthesis and characterization of a series of circular sandwich compounds, cyclocenes, is described, and these cyclic sandwich compounds are expected to lead to further innovations in new functional organometallic materials.
item.dc:title: Synthesis and properties of cyclic sandwich compounds
item.dc:creator: Luca Münzfeld
Sebastian Gillhuber

item.title: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06292-1

Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:title: Revisiting the intrinsic mycobiome in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Ashley A. Fletcher
Matthew S. Kelly
Austin M. Eckhoff
Peter J. Allen

item.title: 3D integration enables ultralow-noise isolator-free lasers in silicon photonics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06251-w

Three-dimensional integration of distributed-feedback lasers and ultralow-loss silicon nitride waveguides results in ultralow-noise lasers without the need for optical isolators.
item.dc:title: 3D integration enables ultralow-noise isolator-free lasers in silicon photonics
item.dc:creator: Chao Xiang

Kerry J. Vahala
John E. Bowers

item.title: Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy shows a warmer modern than medieval climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06176-4

Annually resolved Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy records show that the climate of the current industrial era is substantially warmer than that of the medieval period.
item.dc:title: Fennoscandian tree-ring anatomy shows a warmer modern than medieval climate
item.dc:creator: Jesper Björklund
Kristina Seftigen
Markus Stoffel
Marina V. Fonti
Sven Kottlow

Björn E. Gunnarson
Daniel Nievergelt
Elena Pellizzari
Marco Carrer
Georg von Arx

item.title: A heavyweight early whale pushes the boundaries of vertebrate morphology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06381-1

Perucetus colossus, a basilosaurid whale from the middle Eocene epoch of Peru with an extremely pachyosteosclerotic postcranium, is estimated to have a greater skeletal mass than any known mammal or aquatic vertebrate.
item.dc:title: A heavyweight early whale pushes the boundaries of vertebrate morphology
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Bianucci
Olivier Lambert
Mario Urbina
Marco Merella
Alberto Collareta

Eli Amson

item.title: GPCR activation and GRK2 assembly by a biased intracellular agonist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06395-9

Structural studies on the complex containing G-protein-coupled receptor kinase 2 (GRK2), neurotensin receptor 1 (NTSR1), Gαq and the arrestin-biased ligand SBI-553 provide insights into these interactions and a foundation for the design of arrestin-biased ligands for G-protein-coupled receptors.
item.dc:title: GPCR activation and GRK2 assembly by a biased intracellular agonist
item.dc:creator: Jia Duan

item.title: Ultrafast deposition of faceted lithium polyhedra by outpacing SEI formation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06235-w

We report the discovery of lithium metal’s intrinsic growth morphology, a rhombic dodecahedron, and leverage these rhombic dodecahedra as nucleation seeds for improved battery performance.
item.dc:title: Ultrafast deposition of faceted lithium polyhedra by outpacing SEI formation
item.dc:creator: Xintong Yuan
Bo Liu
Matthew Mecklenburg
Yuzhang Li

item.title: Netrin-1 blockade inhibits tumour growth and EMT features in endometrial cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06367-z

We describe netrin-1 upregulation in a majority of human endometrial carcinomas and demonstrate that netrin-1 blockade, using the anti-netrin-1 antibody NP137, is effective both in a mouse model and in patients with endometrial carcinomas.
item.dc:title: Netrin-1 blockade inhibits tumour growth and EMT features in endometrial cancer

item.title: Scientific discovery in the age of artificial intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06221-2

The advances in artificial intelligence over the past decade are examined, with a discussion on how artificial intelligence systems can aid the scientific process and the central issues that remain despite advances.
item.dc:title: Scientific discovery in the age of artificial intelligence
item.dc:creator: Hanchen Wang

item.title: TDP-43 forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A FTLD-TDP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06405-w

Cryo-electron microscopy structures and mass spectrometry analyses show that TAR DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP-43) forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A frontotemporal lobar degeneration with TDP-43 pathology (FTLD-TDP) compared with TDP-43 filaments in type B FTLD-TDP and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
item.dc:title: TDP-43 forms amyloid filaments with a distinct fold in type A FTLD-TDP
item.dc:creator: Diana Arseni
Renren Chen
Alexey G. Murzin
Sew Y. Peak-Chew
Holly J. Garringer
Kathy L. Newell

Bernardino Ghetti
Masato Hasegawa
Benjamin Ryskeldi-Falcon

item.title: Pharmacological targeting of netrin-1 inhibits EMT in cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06372-2

Netrin-1 is upregulated in cancer models that undergo spontaneous epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, and its targeting blocks the progression of tumour cells to a late mesenchymal state, suggesting possible therapeutic applications.
item.dc:title: Pharmacological targeting of netrin-1 inhibits EMT in cancer
item.dc:creator: Justine Lengrand

item.title: Frustration- and doping-induced magnetism in a Fermi–Hubbard simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06280-5

The magnetic phases of the geometrically frustrated triangular lattice Hubbard model are directly investigated using ultracold fermionic atoms, indicating a possible transition to ferromagnetism at a filling of 1.2.
item.dc:title: Frustration- and doping-induced magnetism in a Fermi–Hubbard simulator
item.dc:creator: Muqing Xu
Lev Haldar Kendrick
Anant Kale
Youqi Gang
Geoffrey Ji
Richard T. Scalettar
Martin Lebrat
Markus Greiner

item.title: Einkorn genomics sheds light on history of the oldest domesticated wheat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06389-7

Around 1% of the A subgenome of modern bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) originates from einkorn (Triticum monococcum), the first domesticated wheat species.
item.dc:title: Einkorn genomics sheds light on history of the oldest domesticated wheat
item.dc:creator: Hanin Ibrahim Ahmed

item.title: Long-term organic carbon preservation enhanced by iron and manganese
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06325-9

Catalysis of simple organic carbon molecules into complex macromolecules by Fe and Mn may play a fundamental role in organic carbon preservation, to a degree that could substantially affect the Earth’s carbon and oxygen cycles.
item.dc:title: Long-term organic carbon preservation enhanced by iron and manganese
item.dc:creator: Oliver W. Moore
Lisa Curti

item.title: Consent document translation expense hinders inclusive clinical trial enrolment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06382-0

The availability of translated consent documents improves recruitment of patients with limited English proficiency to clinical trials, indicating a potentially modifiable barrier to the inclusion of patients with limited English proficiency.
item.dc:title: Consent document translation expense hinders inclusive clinical trial enrolment

item.title: Africa-specific human genetic variation near CHD1L associates with HIV-1 load
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06370-4

Africa-specific genetic variation on chromosome 1 near CHD1L is associated with HIV replication in vivo.
item.dc:title: Africa-specific human genetic variation near CHD1L associates with HIV-1 load

item.title: Quantum oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime in a metal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06330-y

Quantum oscillations in the three-dimensional topological semimetal CoSi are reported, where selected oscillation frequencies have no corresponding extremal Fermi surface cross-sections, representing instead oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime.
item.dc:title: Quantum oscillations of the quasiparticle lifetime in a metal
item.dc:creator: Nico Huber
Valentin Leeb
Andreas Bauer
Georg Benka
Johannes Knolle
Christian Pfleiderer
Marc A. Wilde

item.title: cGAS–STING drives ageing-related inflammation and neurodegeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06373-1

The cGAS–STING signalling pathway is a critical driver of chronic inflammation and functional decline during ageing, and could be targeted to halt neurodegenerative processes during old age.
item.dc:title: cGAS–STING drives ageing-related inflammation and neurodegeneration
item.dc:creator: Muhammet F. Gulen
Natasha Samson

Marius Schwabenland

Selene Glück

Paul Krimpenfort
Marco Prinz
Andrea Ablasser

item.title: The break of earthquake asperities imaged by distributed acoustic sensing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06227-w

Distributed acoustic sensing technology is utilized to image four high-frequency rupture subevents of the 2021 Antelope Valley, California, earthquake; the results indicate that the subevents are due to the breaking of fault asperities.
item.dc:title: The break of earthquake asperities imaged by distributed acoustic sensing
item.dc:creator: Jiaxuan Li
Taeho Kim
Nadia Lapusta
Ettore Biondi
Zhongwen Zhan

item.title: Authigenic mineral phases as a driver of the upper-ocean iron cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06210-5

Analysis of a new dissolved iron, ligand and particulate iron seasonal dataset shows that authigenic iron phases help control ocean dissolved iron distributions and the coupling between dissolved and particulate iron pools.
item.dc:title: Authigenic mineral phases as a driver of the upper-ocean iron cycle
item.dc:creator: Alessandro Tagliabue
Kristen N. Buck
Laura E. Sofen
Benjamin S. Twining
Olivier Aumont

Daniel C. Ohnemus
Bettina Sohst
Peter Sedwick

item.title: Synergy and oxygen adaptation for development of next-generation probiotics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06378-w

The anaerobic gut bacterium Faecalibacterium prausnitzii was isolated and adapted for oxygen tolerance to develop a next-generation probiotic for the treatment of conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease and type 2 diabetes.
item.dc:title: Synergy and oxygen adaptation for development of next-generation probiotics
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Tanweer Khan
Chinmay Dwibedi
Daniel Sundh
Meenakshi Pradhan
Jamie D. Kraft
Robert Caesar
Valentina Tremaroli
Mattias Lorentzon
Fredrik Bäckhed

item.title: Spin-mediated shear oscillators in a van der Waals antiferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06279-y

Using several ultrafast diffraction and microscopy techniques, demagnetization-driven interlayer shear of a van der Waals antiferromagnet is visualized at the nanoscale.
item.dc:title: Spin-mediated shear oscillators in a van der Waals antiferromagnet
item.dc:creator: Alfred Zong
Qi Zhang
Faran Zhou

item.title: Multidecker sandwich compounds assembled into nano-rings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02016-7

Sandwich compounds are molecules in which two planar molecular rings sandwich a metal ion ‘filling’ between them. The chemistry of these compounds has been extended by the assembly of nano-rings from 18 identical sandwich-type building blocks.
item.dc:title: Multidecker sandwich compounds assembled into nano-rings

item.title: Four key questions on the new wave of anti-obesity drugs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02445-4

Scientists want to know who will benefit most, what the long-term effects might be and whether the treatments will change views on obesity.
item.dc:title: Four key questions on the new wave of anti-obesity drugs
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug trials plagued by lack of racial diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02464-1

Under-representation of people of colour sparks concerns over the safety and efficacy of drugs in diverse populations.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug trials plagued by lack of racial diversity
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How the cGAS–STING system links inflammation and cognitive decline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02240-1

When DNA is misplaced inside cells, the cGAS–STING molecular system triggers inflammation. It emerges that stimulation of this mechanism in microglial cells of the brain during ageing contributes to cognitive decline.
item.dc:title: How the cGAS–STING system links inflammation and cognitive decline
item.dc:creator: Bart J. L. Eggen

item.title: Sources of seismic activity imaged using telecom fibre cables
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02019-4

A telecommunications fibre cable was used to capture signals of seismic activity during a moderate-sized earthquake in California in 2021. The signals revealed sources of high-frequency seismic activity and, together with simulations, suggest that these sources arise from breaks in asperities: patches where friction usually locks two sides of a fault together.
item.dc:title: Sources of seismic activity imaged using telecom fibre cables

item.title: Blockade of netrin-1 is a promising strategy against endometrial cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02181-9

The protein netrin-1 is involved in embryonic development and is upregulated in various cancers, including endometrial cancer. In mouse models and a first-in-human trial, blocking netrin-1 with a humanized monoclonal antibody, NP137, prevents a cellular change called the epithelial–mesenchymal transition and inhibits tumour growth.
item.dc:title: Blockade of netrin-1 is a promising strategy against endometrial cancer

item.title: Evolutionary history of world’s oldest domesticated crop
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02375-1

High-quality reference genomes of einkorn wheat, the world’s first domesticated crop, have now been sequenced. The contiguous wheat genome assemblies include gap-free centromeres (parts of the chromosome that are crucial for cell division). The genomes shed light on the evolution of einkorn wheat and provide opportunities for improving wheat and other cereals.
item.dc:title: Evolutionary history of world’s oldest domesticated crop

item.title: Emergent ferromagnetic states revealed in a geometrically frustrated triangular lattice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02387-x

The ordering of magnetic moments in a strongly correlated system depends on the lattice they inhabit, with triangular lattices yielding exotic phases through an effect called geometrical frustration. Experiments demonstrate that ultracold atoms in such lattices show frustration and, surprisingly, display an ordering called ferromagnetism when mobile charges are present.
item.dc:title: Emergent ferromagnetic states revealed in a geometrically frustrated triangular lattice

item.title: A really big fossil whale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02408-9

A newly discovered fossil of an extinct whale from Peru indicates that the animal’s skeleton was unexpectedly enormous. This finding challenges our understanding of body-size evolution.
item.dc:title: A really big fossil whale
item.dc:creator: J. G. M. Thewissen
David A. Waugh

item.title: Improved theory of ocean iron cycle resolves modelling issues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02406-x

A revised conceptual model of the chemical and physical forms of iron in the ocean reconciles the mismatch between observations and simulations of the amount of dissolved iron in seawater — and might aid climate predictions.
item.dc:title: Improved theory of ocean iron cycle resolves modelling issues
item.dc:creator: Brandy M. Toner

item.title: Tight budgets lead to fewer language-diverse participants in academic than industry trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02274-5

Individuals with limited English proficiency were less likely to participate in, and sign consent documents in their primary language for, clinical trials led by academia than those led by industry. This retrospective analysis shows that inadequate funding for translation is a barrier to equitable trial enrolment and appropriate informed consent in academic trials.
item.dc:title: Tight budgets lead to fewer language-diverse participants in academic than industry trials

item.title: Contrariwise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02449-0

Storage management.
item.dc:title: Contrariwise
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Tessmer

item.title: Daily briefing: Proposed ban on ‘forever chemicals’ fuels debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02484-x

As a European agency considers a PFAS ban, scientists ponder which uses of fluorinated chemicals are truly essential. Plus, genetically engineered cells produce insulin when they feel electricity and the world’s largest trials for long-COVID treatments launch.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Proposed ban on ‘forever chemicals’ fuels debate
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Variation in African genomes linked to control of HIV
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02277-2

Genomic analyses of individuals living with HIV-1 revealed a region in chromosome 1 that is associated with reduced viral loads specifically in populations with African ancestry. This could point to much-needed therapeutic targets to address the global public-health crisis caused by HIV-1.
item.dc:title: Variation in African genomes linked to control of HIV

item.title: Wood-anatomy data refine the record of climate in Northern Europe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02010-z

Reconstructions of past temperatures often portray the extended warm period known as the Medieval Climate Anomaly (ad 950–1250) as warmer than the current period. However, a set of wood-anatomy measurements from tree rings shows that the North European climate is much warmer today than it was during that time, underscoring the role of anthropogenic climate change in the region’s temperature variability.
item.dc:title: Wood-anatomy data refine the record of climate in Northern Europe

item.title: ChatGPT-like AIs are coming to major science search engines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02470-3

Scopus, Dimensions and Web of Science are introducing conversational AI search.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT-like AIs are coming to major science search engines
item.dc:creator: Richard Van Noorden

item.title: Lithium forms perfect polyhedra in ultrafast-charging batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02013-w

The performance of next-generation batteries is closely linked to the shape of deposits of metallic lithium that form during charging. Experiments in ultrafast-charging batteries have now revealed that lithium intrinsically forms geometrically perfect 12-face polyhedra, independently of various factors that were long thought to affect the shape of lithium deposits.
item.dc:title: Lithium forms perfect polyhedra in ultrafast-charging batteries

item.title: Turning cooperative bacteria into probiotics for human health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02407-w

Understanding how our gut bacteria combine forces to co-exist and produce beneficial molecules will be crucial for developing next-generation probiotics. Key progress towards achieving this goal has been made.
item.dc:title: Turning cooperative bacteria into probiotics for human health
item.dc:creator: Yolanda Sanz

item.title: Could this ancient whale be the heaviest animal ever?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02457-0

Massive vertebrae and other fossilized remains found in Peru point to an Eocene-epoch beast of colossal proportions.
item.dc:title: Could this ancient whale be the heaviest animal ever?
item.dc:creator: Emma Marris

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02442-7

Climate change is making water stress worse for billions worldwide. Scaling up both new and traditional solutions must be a priority.
item.dc:title: Water crisis: how local technologies can help solve a global problem

item.content:encoded:

item.title: A call to reduce the carbon costs of forest harvest
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02238-9

Economic modelling of the global carbon cost of harvesting wood from forests shows a much higher annual cost than that estimated by other models, highlighting a major opportunity for reducing emissions by limiting wood harvests.
item.dc:title: A call to reduce the carbon costs of forest harvest
item.dc:creator: William R. Moomaw
Beverly E. Law

item.title: Anna Atkins: pioneering botanical photographer who captured algae and ferns in ghostly blue images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02446-3

A compilation of 550 original plates reveals the dedicated work of the nineteenth-century woman who was the first to publish a book with cyanotypes of specimens.
item.dc:title: Anna Atkins: pioneering botanical photographer who captured algae and ferns in ghostly blue images
item.dc:creator: Georgina Ferry

item.title: Daily briefing: Fruit flies genetically engineered for ‘virgin birth’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02474-z

For the first time, female animals were genetically engineered to reproduce without a male partner. Plus, ‘sloppy’ data mar spectacular superconductor claims.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Fruit flies genetically engineered for ‘virgin birth’
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Threatened Mexican oasis loses its main researcher and protector — will it survive?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02413-y

Valeria Souza has long fought the drainage of the Cuatro Ciénegas basin, where ancient microbes offer clues to the origins of life.
item.dc:title: Threatened Mexican oasis loses its main researcher and protector — will it survive?
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero
